title: Which logic family dissipate the minimum power? A) DTL. B) TTL. C) ECL. D) CMOS. E) None of the above - Quora

response.answer_text: CMOS is the lowest power of those. Rather than resistive pull-up and down, complementary MOS transistors are used for both pull-up and down. Simple CMOS devices use almost no power when not switching from one state to another. When switching, a momentary tiny pulse of current is taken - as the transistors change state. Power taken is therefore roughly proportional to switching frequency.

This is a poorly worded homework question. I suggest you look up the various logic families (you can do this in Wikipedia) and learn for yourself. I will give a hint by saying only one of these dissipates zero static power (in other words, it only dissipates power when inputs change.)
